problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments : Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

constraints:
# -- Constraints --


# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def fit_items_in_box(items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item), 
                     positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position), 
                     assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
                     box_width: int, 
                     box_height: int):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Item must fit within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= box_width
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= box_height
        # Position coordinates must be non-negative (already constrained by Field definitions)
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].y >= 0

fit_items_in_box(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments, BOX_WIDTH, BOX_HEIGHT)

# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap(items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item), 
               positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position), 
               assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check overlap if items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlap in x-axis
                x_non_overlap: bool = (positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x) or \
                                      (positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x)
                # Check for non-overlap in y-axis
                y_non_overlap: bool = (positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y) or \
                                      (positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y)
                # Assert that at least one axis has non-overlap (i.e., rectangles do not overlap)
                assert x_non_overlap or y_non_overlap

no_overlap(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_assignment_validity(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)),
                                    nr_boxes: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Each item must be assigned to a box number between 1 and nr_used_boxes
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= nr_boxes

ensure_item_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments, nr_used_boxes)
full_formulation:
# --- Objects ---


# Object type for an item with width and height
Item = DSRecord({
    "width": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40),
    "height": DSInt(lb=1, ub=40)
})

# Object type for the position (x, y) of an item within a box
Position = DSRecord({
    "x": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40),
    "y": DSInt(lb=0, ub=40)
})



# --- Constants and Decision Variables ---
BOX_HEIGHT : int = 40
BOX_WIDTH : int = 40
ITEMS : DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item) = [{"width": 34, "height": 13}, {"width": 5, "height": 32}, {"width": 6, "height": 13}, {"width": 32, "height": 33}, {"width": 22, "height": 6}, {"width": 29, "height": 34}, {"width": 15, "height": 20}, {"width": 23, "height": 17}, {"width": 2, "height": 23}, {"width": 18, "height": 9}, {"width": 9, "height": 31}, {"width": 29, "height": 14}, {"width": 5, "height": 35}, {"width": 14, "height": 11}, {"width": 6, "height": 6}, {"width": 12, "height": 29}, {"width": 4, "height": 28}, {"width": 3, "height": 1}, {"width": 3, "height": 24}, {"width": 14, "height": 13}]
N_ITEMS : int = 20
nr_used_boxes : DSInt(lb=1, ub=20)
item_box_assignments : DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
x_y_positions : DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position)
N_ITEMS : int = 20
N_ITEM_BOX_ASSIGNMENTS : int = 20
N_X_Y_POSITIONS : int = 20


# --- objective ---
def calculate_objective(assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))) -> DSInt(lb=1, ub=20):
    max_box: DSInt(lb=1, ub=20) = assignments[1]
    for i in range(2, N_ITEMS + 1):
        if assignments[i] > max_box:
            max_box = assignments[i]
    return max_box

objective = calculate_objective(item_box_assignments)
nr_used_boxes = objective
minimize(objective)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

):

        # Ensure items fit within the box dimensions

):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):

):

        assert box_assignments[i] >= 1
        assert box_assignments[i] <= nr_used_boxes
        
        # Position coordinates must be non-negative (ensured by Field bounds)
        assert positions[i].x >= 0
        assert positions[i].y >= 0

ensure_item_assignment_consistency(item_box_assignments, x_y_positions, nr_used_boxes)

problem_description:
Global problem:
    This problem involves a collection of items, where each have a value and a weight. We have different items given in the parameters.
    We have a infinite number of boxes with width BOX_WIDTH and height BOX_HEIGHT. All items need to be packed into minimal number of such boxes.
    The result and expected output is:
        - the assigment of each item into a box
        - the position (x and y) of each item within its assigned box. x and y have minimum values 0 and maximum infinity.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 1:
    The items that are put into a box, must fit exactly inside the box and must not stick out of the box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 2:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, they must not overlap.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

Sub problem definition - items that go in the bin - part 3:
    Taking the given items that are put into a box, one item can be exactly in one box.
    The result and expected output is the assignment of each item into a box and the position of each item within its assigned box.

constants.description: List of items with their dimensions

decision_variables.description: Number of boxes used in the end to pack all all items. Minimizing it is the objective.
Which item is assigned to which box as a separate variable.
decision_variables.initialization: item_box_assignments: Annotated[list[Annotated[int, Field(strict=True, ge=1, le=20)]], Len(20, 20)]

decision_variables.description: Position x and y of each item within box as a separate variable.

def items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        # Ensure item fits within the box dimensions
        assert positions[i].x + items[i].width <= BOX_WIDTH
        assert positions[i].y + items[i].height <= BOX_HEIGHT

# Call the constraint function with required arguments
items_fit_exactly_in_boxes(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- Auxiliary Variables ---
# Leave empty, if not required.
# --- constraints ---
def no_overlap_constraints(
    items: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Item),
    positions: DSList(length=20, elem_type=Position),
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        for j in range(i + 1, N_ITEMS + 1):
            # Only check for overlap if both items are in the same box
            if assignments[i] == assignments[j]:
                # Check for non-overlapping conditions
                # Either i is to the left of j
                # Or i is to the right of j
                # Or i is below j
                # Or i is above j
                assert (
                    positions[i].x + items[i].width <= positions[j].x or
                    positions[j].x + items[j].width <= positions[i].x or
                    positions[i].y + items[i].height <= positions[j].y or
                    positions[j].y + items[j].height <= positions[i].y
                )

no_overlap_constraints(ITEMS, x_y_positions, item_box_assignments)

# --- constraints ---
def ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(
    assignments: DSList(length=20, elem_type=DSInt(lb=1, ub=20))
):
    # Each item must be assigned to exactly one box (already ensured by domain)
    # Here we enforce that the assignment respects the objective:
    # The number of boxes used is minimized, so all assignments should be contiguous
    # from box 1 upwards. This means if box k is used, then all boxes 1..k-1 are also used.
    # To model this, we ensure that if box b is used (i.e., there exists an item in box b),
    # then for every box b' < b, box b' is also used.
    # We don't need to explicitly check this; minimizing the max box index will naturally lead to compact usage.
    # However, we can add a redundant constraint to strengthen the model:
    # For any two boxes b1 < b2, if b2 is used, then b1 must also be used implicitly by minimization.
    # Since we're minimizing the highest box index, gaps won't occur in optimal solutions.
    # So we just verify that assignments respect bounds and each item maps to one box.
    for i in range(1, N_ITEMS + 1):
        assert assignments[i] >= 1
        assert assignments[i] <= 20

ensure_item_box_assignment_validity(item_box_assignments)
